quotes.text: 80% of the culture of a company is literally defined by the personality of the founder. Our job as operators or as leaders is to help articulate the culture that they're creating.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for how founder personality shapes culture—and what operators should focus on to scale it intentionally.

quotes.text: You have to grow as fast as your company is growing if you really want to take advantage, both learning to give away what you've gotten good at and move on to the next shiny pile of Legos.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for leaders in hypergrowth: deliberately shed responsibilities and re-skill to keep pace with the company.

quotes.text: He said, the way a lot of people do careers is a set of stairs. Just walk up the stairs and you'll get promoted every two years. But that is boring. The much more fun careers are like jumping off cliffs and you do fall, but then you climb out way beyond where the stairs could ever get you.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career-growth framework (J-curve vs. stairs) that encourages taking risky leaps to unlock outsized advancement.

quotes.text: Ami Vora, who you have had on your podcast, once said to me that all advice is just someone telling you what they did.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A useful lens for evaluating leadership advice—treat it as contextual experience, not universal truth.

quotes.text: I really think that basically what I tell people is I've made every single mistake in the book. And then I got to the end of the book and I started inventing new mistakes.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A memorable framing that positions her frameworks as hard-won lessons from repeated failure—useful for normalizing mistakes during scale.

quotes.text: Ami Vora, who you have had on your podcast, once said to me that all advice is just someone telling you what they did.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A useful mental model for evaluating advice by tracing it back to the advisor’s lived context and incentives.

quotes.text: I only like doing jobs that I'm highly unqualified for. I like being on learning curves so steep that I'm scared I'm going to fall off.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career-growth heuristic: deliberately choose roles that force rapid learning through discomfort.

quotes.text: the experience of building something from nothing is actually quite different than the experience of holding on for dear life while things are scaling so fast around you.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A practical distinction that helps leaders pick the right skills and expectations for zero-to-one vs. hypergrowth environments.

quotes.text: my department, which was the communications department, was 25 people when I joined and it grew in nine months to 125 people.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A concrete scaling data point illustrating how quickly team structure and leadership demands can change.

quotes.text: Essentially what does it take to thrive inside growing and changing companies, not just to hang on for dear life. What does it take to lead in the face of constant change?
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A leadership framing that shifts the goal from survival to thriving and leading amid continuous change.

quotes.text: To thrive in the AI era, organizations need to adapt quickly.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (DX)
quotes.context: A concise strategic imperative that frames adaptability as a core capability for AI-era success.

quotes.text: But many organization leaders struggle to answer pressing questions like, which tools are working? How are they being used? What's actually driving value?
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (DX)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical diagnostic framework leaders can use to evaluate AI/tooling impact: effectiveness, usage, and value drivers.

quotes.text: If you're a founder, the hardest part of starting a company isn't having the idea. It's scaling the business without getting buried in back office work.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Brex)
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing of startup difficulty that emphasizes operational scaling over ideation.

quotes.text: One in three startups in the United States already runs on Brex.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Brex)
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals market penetration and social proof.

quotes.text: And for me, learning this muscle of both learning to give away what you've gotten good at and move on to the next shiny pile of Legos. And learning that the emotions associated with that are inevitable.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Frames “giving away your Legos” as a repeatable skill (a muscle) and normalizes the emotional resistance as part of the process.

quotes.text: That is both the torment of scaling companies, which is that the ground is moving under your feet. And as soon as you're comfortable, someone will make sure that you are uncomfortable, but it's also the opportunity, which is that you can go from being someone that's good at building houses to someone that knows how to build entire worlds.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Recasts constant role disruption in scaling companies as the mechanism for compounding scope and capability over time.

quotes.text: That means that if you actually just stay and build houses, eventually you're literally buried under a pile of Legos.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A vivid warning that clinging to what you’re good at becomes unsustainable as the company (and job) expands.

quotes.text: At Facebook, I got to a place where I was literally giving away my job every three weeks. I was constantly rehiring myself essentially because you have to sort of grow as fast as your company is growing if you really want to take advantage of the opportunity that comes with companies that are growing and changing quickly.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A concrete example and operating cadence for rapid growth: repeatedly hand off scope and “rehire yourself” into the next problem.

quotes.text: So basically I externalized all these emotions that come with change into this little tiny monster. I named my monster, Bob.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for separating unhelpful emotions from your identity so you can observe them without acting on them.

quotes.text: But Bob's job is to make you the worst version of yourself. So your job is to let Bob do his thing, but not act on the emotions.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for emotion regulation during change: allow feelings to exist without letting them drive behavior.

quotes.text: Basically, all these emotions are normal and they are not useful. They are not the compass that should be telling you what to do.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe that normal reactions to change shouldn’t automatically be treated as decision signals.

quotes.text: So my rule of thumb from Facebook was give it two weeks.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable heuristic for distinguishing transient emotional waves from persistent issues worth addressing.

quotes.text: But anything that lasts longer than two weeks is actually something you should pay attention to. It's something that if it's been around for two weeks, it's something you should go talk to someone about.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Clear escalation advice: persistent feelings are a signal to seek input from a manager, friend, or coach rather than white-knuckling it.

quotes.topic_title: When to resist change vs embrace it
quotes.text: A lot of times I think inside of change, we get focused on the past, and one of the most valuable things you can do as a manager and a leader is help people focus on the future.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A practical leadership move during change is to deliberately redirect attention from what was lost to what can be built next.

quotes.topic_title: When to resist change vs embrace it
quotes.text: So in general, I would just say, step into the future and let the past go and see what you're going to learn.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for navigating uncertainty: treat change as a learning path rather than something to resist.

quotes.topic_title: When to resist change vs embrace it
quotes.text: Holding onto things almost always leads us to the worst version of ourselves.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that attachment can degrade judgment and behavior, especially in organizational change.

quotes.topic_title: When to resist change vs embrace it
quotes.text: A friend of mine says, careers are long and nobody tells you that. But they're long.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A reframing tool for high-stress moments: zoom out to a longer time horizon to reduce panic and make better decisions.

quotes.topic_title: When to resist change vs embrace it
quotes.text: The most interesting careers are winding and they have starts and stops and failures and successes and control. Anybody that's been through a lot of this stuff, control is usually not the name of the game. It's usually just like, "Let's see what happens. We're going to try this and we're going to see what happens next."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A career mental model that normalizes nonlinear paths and emphasizes experimentation over trying to control outcomes.

quotes.text: The way a lot of people do careers is a set of stairs. "You can be boring." To use Chamath, "And stay on these stairs. Just walk up the stairs and you'll get promoted every two years and your title will change from manager to senior manager to director to senior director, whatever."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Defines the conventional “stairs” model of career progression with predictable promotions and titles.

quotes.text: And he's like, "The much more fun careers are like jumping off cliffs." Basically, that you jump off this thing and you do fall for a period of time. I always like to say it's about six to nine months, but then this thing happens where you climb out.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Introduces the J-curve “cliff jump” model and sets an expectation for a 6–9 month learning dip before growth.

quotes.text: I spent the next six months feeling like an absolute idiot. I basically felt like a total jackass all the time. I was sitting in rooms with these brilliant people asking the dumbest questions of my life and at the end of the six months, Chamath, I think, took a lot of pride in giving me the lowest performance rating I've ever gotten in my life, and it just felt like falling off a cliff.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A concrete example of the painful “dip” phase that often accompanies taking on a role you’re unqualified for.

quotes.text: The phone itself was a giant failure, massive, costly failure for Facebook, but it was not a failure for me.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson that even “failed” projects can be career accelerators if they build rare skills.

quotes.text: you can get these opportunities that you are just so deeply unqualified for, but they can take you to places that you could never have imagined.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Actionable advice to say yes to stretch opportunities in fast-growing environments because they can unlock outsized growth.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
quotes.text: I use finances because it's the most concrete example of a type of fear that you should actually listen to.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Distinguishes “good” fear (financial risk you should quantify and respect) from fear that’s just discomfort.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
quotes.text: What is the number that you need to hit so that you're not constantly terrified financially?
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A practical prompt for calculating personal runway/burn rate before making a risky career move.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
quotes.text: And that's the kind of fear that I think of as a flashing green light because... And it sounds like Matt McGinnis said this too, where it's like, "That's the kind of fear that's saying, 'Why don't you go prove to yourself that you are actually capable of this?'"
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Reframes capability fear as a signal to lean in and grow rather than a warning to avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
quotes.text: I always say, "Specific financial anxiety is much more useful than existential financial anxiety."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mindset shift: turn vague money fear into concrete math and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
quotes.text: one of the greatest gifts in a career is knowing yourself. And that's a lifelong journey because who you are and what you want changes, but that knowledge and that gift, nothing accelerates your self-knowledge faster than trying to do something that you don't know how to do and that you're scared of.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A career-growth methodology: use scary, unfamiliar challenges as the fastest path to self-knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
quotes.text: I always say, "The most important thing to do in the falling phase and the risk taking land is to learn to embrace being a professional idiot."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A memorable framework for navigating the early J-curve dip by prioritizing learning over looking competent.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
quotes.text: But then you get brave and you ask it and it turns out it wasn't a dumb question. Do you know what I mean? Turns out that everyone had that question in their mind, but no one was brave enough to ask it.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice that “basic” questions often unlock shared confusion and accelerate group clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
quotes.text: So, from a skills' perspective, again, regardless of outcome, being the person that sort of takes their learning in their own hands, learning no matter what and learning to ask those dumb questions, it's a superpower.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: treat self-directed learning and asking naive questions as a repeatable career advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
quotes.text: And he realized that he needs to be not a 10X PM, but a 10X learner, and that's what people actually expect from someone, especially a junior person.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical reframing of performance expectations: optimize for learning velocity rather than immediate excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
quotes.text: Somebody once told... I'm sure this is faster now, but they rewrote the entire code base at Google every eight years, which means that if you're not learning, if you're not evolving, then you become irrelevant and extinct.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A concrete example underscoring why continuous learning is mandatory in fast-changing environments.

quotes.text: The interesting thing about this model is that most people, when something's going wrong on a team, a lot of times we always go to the bottom. We go to the people. We're like, "The people aren't getting along, that person's having a rough moment." We go to the humans, but the rule with the Waterline Model, which is very memorable, is you snorkel before you scuba. So, 80% of problems on teams actually happen because of structural issues or dynamics issues. So, when there are problems on your team, where you start is at the top, you start structural issues.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnostic rule-of-thumb: start with structure/dynamics before blaming individuals, backed by an 80% claim.

quotes.text: And one of my biggest things that I say all the time over and over again inside of Glue Club is, "Your only goal as a manager, if you do nothing else, is clear roles and clear expectations. That's it."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A highly actionable management priority that simplifies what to focus on first to prevent many downstream issues.

quotes.text: Every company I've worked with or advise, I often start with like, "What are the goals?" And usually what you get the hack is, "Uh, not clear." And that in and of itself is a structural issue, right? How can someone show up and decide what they're going to do with their day all day if the goals aren't clear, if they don't actually know what the priorities are?
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A practical starting question for diagnosing team dysfunction: unclear goals create day-to-day execution paralysis.

quotes.text: And that equation, again, I would say 80% of problems that I see, performance issues. I always start with, "Does this person actually know what you expect of them?" If not, go back to step one.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A repeatable troubleshooting sequence for performance issues: verify expectations clarity before escalating to people problems.

quotes.topic_title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
quotes.text: So a lot of times what I do is two-sided, right? So it's like, "Hey, here's what I'm seeing and tell me what's going on for you. Do you know X, Y, Z?"
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable structure for addressing performance or alignment issues through two-way dialogue rather than one-way feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
quotes.text: When I take over a team, when I'm doing my listening tour, part of what I'm asking is, "What do you think your job is? What number were you hired to drive?"
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A concrete set of diagnostic questions to surface mismatched expectations about role, ownership, and success metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
quotes.text: You think you've been clear, you described an elephant and they spat out a tiger and that coming back to like, "Okay, no, we're building an elephant. You're in charge of the trunk."
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for how miscommunication happens and how leaders can re-anchor teams on the real goal and each person’s scope.

quotes.topic_title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
quotes.text: But yeah, I would say two-way dialogue, but re-clarifying roles and expectations, re-describing the elephant over and over and over again, is one of the hardest parts about being a leader because you feel like a broken record, right?
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: Highlights the leadership reality that alignment requires repetition, even when it feels inefficient or redundant.

quotes.topic_title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
quotes.text: You're like, "I've said this 45 times." Turns out no one heard you the first 43 and you have to.
quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that communication doesn’t “stick” without repeated reinforcement, especially as teams scale.
